info.p: This is a stand-in for when a centre wishes to declare that it accepts certain kinds of source code or discourages certain kinds of submissions of this nature. A recommendation using this "umbrella format" must be accompanied by a comment.

As is usual with umbrella formats, centres are strongly encouraged to, firstly, check if the programming or query language code they wish to reference is among the formats already described in the SIS or formats that await getting described. At the time when this description is updated, the following kinds of "source code" already have individual descriptions:

A simplifying explicit assumption is that this umbrella (pseudo-)format belongs to the "plain-text" family. The practical consequence of that is that formats that constitute source code but are based on XML, such as Scalable Vector Graphics or XSLT need to be classified separately. While that can be seen as a semantic impoverishment of the extension of the notion of "source code", it is very likely that, on the intuitive plane, the restriction is quite fitting.

An additional assumption is that there is no clear boundary between programming languages and query languages. That is pretty clear when looking from the programming language perspective, so it is only a tiny step to add the view from the opposite side and classify SQL as a subtype scrCode as well.
